definitions.definition: to put somebody/something in a particular position, especially when it is done gently or carefully
definitions.sensetop: lay somebody/something + adv./prep.lay somethinglay somebody/something + adj.

examples.text: He laid a hand on my arm.
Relatives **laid wreaths** on the grave.
She laid the baby down gently on the bed.
Red roses were laid at the memorial.
She noticed some paintings laid against the far wall.
The horse laid back its ears.
His mother visited the murder scene yesterday to lay flowers.
The cloth should be laid flat.
She laid the clothes neatly on her bed.
He laid the child tenderly on the bed.

definitions.definition: to spread something on something; to cover something with a layer of something
definitions.sensetop: lay A on/over BB is laid with A

examples.text: Before they started they laid newspaper on the floor.
The grapes were laid to dry on racks.
They carefully laid a blanket over the body.
The floor was laid with newspaper.

definitions.definition: to put something down, especially on the floor, ready to be used

examples.text: to lay a carpet/cable/pipe
to lay tiles/bricks
The first high-speed track was laid between Paris and Lyons.
Thirteen U-boats left their base to lay mines in British waters.
The foundations of the house are being laid today.
A series of short-term goals **lays the foundation** for long-term success.
They had **laid the groundwork** for future development.

definitions.definition: if a bird, an insect, a fish, etc. lays eggs, it produces them from its body

examples.text: The cuckoo **lays** its **eggs** in other birds' nests.
new-laid eggs
The hens are not laying well *(= not producing many eggs)*.

definitions.definition: to arrange knives, forks, plates, etc. on a table ready for a meal

examples.text: to lay the table

definitions.definition: to present a proposal, some information, etc. to somebody for them to think about and decide on

examples.text: The bill was laid before Parliament.

definitions.definition: to put somebody/something in a particular position or state, especially a difficult or unpleasant one

examples.text: to lay a responsibility/burden on somebody
to lay somebody under an obligation to do something
Failing to act now will merely lay the burden on future generations.

definitions.definition: used with a noun to form a phrase that has the same meaning as the verb related to the noun

examples.text: to **lay the blame** on somebody *(= to blame somebody)*
Our teacher lays great stress on good spelling *(= stresses it strongly)*.
She laid the blame for the crisis at the Prime Minister's door.
He laid stress on the importance of cooperation.
Little did he know they had laid a trap for him.
She began to **lay her plans** for her escape.
Bad weather can upset even the **best-laid** plans.
He went out hoping to **get laid** that night.

definitions.definition: to prepare a fire by arranging wood, sticks or coal
to bet money on something; to place a bet
definitions.sensetop: lay somethinglay something on somethinglay (somebody) something (that)…

examples.text: to lay a bet
She had laid $100 on the favourite.
I think he’ll come, but I wouldn’t lay money on it.
I’ll lay you any money you like (that) he won’t come.

wordOrigin: verb Old English lecgan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch leggen and German legen, also to lie.
